meta_data.title: The Clothes Maketh the Man
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 3:26-29 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: 🎵 Yesterday I threw out a quick reference to an old saying, The Clothes Make It The Man. Do you know where that comes from? I did not know where that comes from. I thought I knew, but I was wrong. I've been pulling on the thread of that pun intended today. I'd like to report my findings. We'll see if you knew more about this than I did. I thought it was from The Kingsman, which is a couple of movies that have come out recently. You might like movies like that, you might not. You should watch things, you want to watch them. I'm out in charge of that. I'm not recommending anything. Disclaimer, disclaimer, disclaimer. But it's not. The saying isn't The Clothes Make It The Man. It's a movie where a street smart kid from the UK gets roped into an ancient secret society of peace keepers and secret agents who do what needs to be done behind the scenes, but they do it all with great dignity and a plum. And so they wear certain outfits that are reflective of the dignity of their station and their responsibility. But they don't say The Clothes Make It The Man. They're saying is manners make it The Man. But they say that while they're changing the kid's wardrobe and getting him on board with this. So I think it kind of counts, but it's not from there. So I went back a little further. And there were people who thought that the saying came from the show, Mad Men with Paul, John Hamm and Tony Stark's dad. I don't know the name of that actor. And Richard Harris's son. What's his name? What's Richard Harris's kid's name? He's a great actor. He was in Chernobyl. How do I not have this? Somebody in the Patreon thread is going to know his name, and I'm going to feel like an idiot. And you are going to be smarter than me, and I respect your smartness. But I went and I look closer, and I don't think they ever say the clothes make it The Man in Mad Men. It's just an underlying motif that comes up a whole bunch through the course of the show. Maybe I'm wrong on that. So I dug a little deeper. Turns out Mark Twain had a clothes make it The Man quote that was something like clothes often make The Man. Naked people have little influence on society. Oh, that's kind of clever. Mark Twain makes all these kind of quotes more fun, right? So Lady Gudiva, The Emperor with no clothes. I don't know, maybe that's not a rabbit hole that you and I want to go down. But the clothes make it The Man rabbit hole is one I want to go down. So I kept pulling on the thread, and it turns out that I figured out what I recognized it from. It's from Hamlet. Did you remember this? Polonius, the guy who could stab through the curtain, the old nosy dad type, grandpa type, he at one point says something to the effect for the apparel oft proclameth the man. That's close at any rate. I remember that. I saw Mel Gibson's Hamlet when I was a kid and then I've had to read it a whole bunch of timesense. There we go. So I figured that was probably it. But it turns out the saying goes back even further. Erasmus of Rotterdam, who was a scholar who did a whole bunch of research linguistically that set Martin Luther up for his translation of the New Testament. He also gathered a bunch of ancient Latin proverbs and sayings. And one of them in his collection, I should have remembered what the name of the collection was, is Collectia something, something. Thestis Virum Thasset, the clothes make it the man. Huh, there we go. So maybe that's where it comes from. But then I pull on the thread a little more and it turns out that there are a couple of nods to that turn of a phrase in ancient Greek literature even in Homer, which is forever as he's old. So the point is the saying the clothes make it the man is about as old as culture and man itself. Apparently everybody from all cultures across all time has figured out that there is something about how one presents themselves. There's something about what someone is robed in that tells a story and at least partially creates a feedback loop that informs back on who that person is in their essence and how other people regard that person. Well, I'll tell you what other ancient document seems to hold that position. The Bible surprise, there's your transition. Ta-da! At the end of Galatians chapter three, we get sort of this clothes make it the man-type assumption, type statement about what it is to be in Christ. Galatians three, Paul writing it, says you are all sons of God through faith in Christ Jesus. It's a very permanent language. You are this, you're not gonna be unsund later. You're all sons of God because of what God has done, the cross and faith in Christ. And God's done the heavy lift. We know that from the rest of Galatians. He goes on, for all of you who were baptized into Christ, here it comes, have clothed yourselves with Christ. There we go, there's a nod to that. Very ancient, very multicultural idea that the clothes make it the man. Well, in this case, it's God who is making the man. It's God who is assigning that essence. It is God who is making this robing, this clothing possible. But this is not a one-off quote that just happens right here in the Bible. This is a huge motif, a huge, and I dare say, often overlooked motif in the Bible of putting something on and that having profound theological meaning, profound implications for the essence of the wearer. And you're probably thinking to yourself, I know what it means when you get that look in your eye, you're about to take us on a multi-day arc through the Bible where we go and explore all of the things about the clothes make a thing the man and about the motif of being robed in the righteousness of God throughout the Bible. And come on, we gotta move forward at some point. I'm not just gonna, okay, if you really want me to, that's what we'll do then. Let's start deep in the Old Testament, all the way back in the book of Genesis, we see the idea of clothing happening in the garden. And really, the clothing that is put on there is reflective of the curse. Genesis 3.6, and remember, Adam and Eve at this point, they are buck naked every last bit is out there for everybody to see, but then they eat the fruit and the serpent tempts them, but then this happens. When the woman saw that the fruit of the tree was good for food and pleasing to the eye and also desirable for gaining wisdom, she took some of it and ate it. She also gave some to her husband who was with her and he ate it. Then the eyes of both of them were opened and they realized they were naked. So they sewed fig leaves together and made coverings for themselves. Isn't it interesting that the fig leaves are a metaphor for shame and guilt before God? They've robed themselves in something that is a reminder of this new problem that's been introduced. Sin, the human condition. In a minute, we're about to find out that with all of that comes death and separation from God. But here we are, only three chapters into the Bible and the motif of being robed in something that means something is already on screen. How about Genesis 27? Maybe some of you will remember this story. There are two brothers, Jacob and Esau. Esau apparently was real hairy and he was the older brother just barely. And so he was set to inherit his blind dad's inheritance. It's Isaac, but Jacob and his mom cook up a plan for how they're gonna steal the inheritance. How do they do it? Robing, the clothes make it the man. So Jacob puts on some hairy goat skins and goes in there to his dad with some yummy soup and it's like, I heard some soup. Probably better get your blessing and your inheritance now. And his dad's like, let me just make sure your arms are hairy enough. Let me just check that. Okay, that seems hairy enough. Here you go. And he reels off this beautiful blessing. And apparently the ground rules of giving this kind of blessing and inheritance is that you can't take it back. There's no take back sees. So Esau finds out, he's like, what the heck, man? And his dad's like, oh, man, sorry. And his dad's like, ah, rats, there's no take backs on those. So that's just how it is. And it sets in motion a whole arc of the plot. Again, here's this motif of putting on something in the Old Testament, not fully paid off yet. It's just a motif that is sitting out there and pregnant waiting for more meaning to be applied to it. Then in Genesis 37, you get Joseph and his dad's favorite and what happens? He gets robed in a coat of many colors. What happens when his brothers get jealous and angry of that and they decide they want to do away with him? They strip him of the honor that was put on him by his father in the position that he holds by disrobing him, by taking the robe away. They disrobe him. The clothes mecca, the man, he had been robed in honor. Now he's not robed in honor. But as is so often the case in the Bible, there's a grand reversal in Genesis 41 when Joseph gets sold into slavery in Egypt without his coat. And he's even completely stripped all the way down to being naked at one point in the process of this. Completely vulnerable and dependent on God as he flees from some lady who's trying to seduce him. Buck naked, just like Adam and Eve out there in the garden. If the clothes make of the man, Joseph is in a bad state. He's got nothing cooking other than God. Yet God reverses the fortunes and restores him. And in Genesis 41, 41 and 42, it says, so Pharaoh said to Joseph, I hereby put you in charge of the whole land of Egypt. Then Pharaoh took his signet ring from his finger and put it on Joseph's finger. He dressed him in robes of fine linen and put gold chains around his neck. The clothes make it the man. Joseph went from being buck naked and on the run to wearing the royal vestments of the king. That tells a story about God's blessing. It tells a story about who Joseph is now and how he is to be regarded. And it's a motif that really is meant to pay off later when we get to language like what we get to in Galatians 3. The royal vestments of the kingdom of God placed upon you and I, former slaves, former subjects of the law, slaves to death, outsiders, foreigners, all of a sudden, we're adopted, we're brought in, we're maids, sons and daughters and robed in the clothing that marks us as members of the household of God, heirs to the kingdom. The Bible's an incredibly unified book. Motifs do not happen on accident. Those things are supposed to be there. Obviously, I wanna go all the way down the rabbit hole right now, I wanna do that every day, but we try to hit the time constraint thing here. So I'm just gonna pause, no panic. We're gonna keep going on our jaunt through the Old Testament looking at this clothes, make it the man and the clothes are a gift from God. Motif and how it sets things up for the New Testament and how it pays off here in Galatians 3. We're gonna just keep working through that tomorrow. All right, that's good for now. I'm Matt, this is the 10 Minute Bible Hour Podcast. Let's do this again soon.
